title: Question 8
prompt:
Anna is analyzing her greeting card business’s profits. She wants more than 40% of the price of her greeting cards to be profit. If 
<math><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>c</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
 represents Anna’s cost to make a greeting card, and 
<math><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>p</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
 represents the price Anna charges for the card, which inequality represents Anna’s desired profit?
description: Click the <u>one best answer</u> to each question.
feedback:
The inequality 
<math><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>p</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>></mo><mi>p</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>%</mo></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
 represents a profit of more than 40%. The left side of the inequality, 
<math><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>p</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
, is price minus cost. The price, minus the cost, is the profit. For example, if Anna spent $1.00 making a greeting card and sold it for $2.00, she would make $1.00 profit (the price minus the cost. The right side of the inequality, 
<math><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>p</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>%</mo></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
 represents 40% of the price of the cards, the amount of profit Anna wants to beat. Together, the inequality says profit (
<math><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>p</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
) is greater than (
<math><mtable><mtr><mtd><mo>></mo></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
) 40% of the price (
<math><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>p</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>%</mo></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
).
